This is honestly brilliant, since not only is it a tribute to Technoblade, but it would add a leading figure among the Piglins as well as add a potentially stronger mob. Either way, I love the idea.

Make it so that killing him might get you the crown, also make the crown give you strength effect or something. Maybe let him trade with you by gold blocks. Let him be able to sell you bows, armor, and swords. Wearing the crown should also make all the piglins neutral towards you. Make him a mini boss too, who can dodge arrows and have better reach than other mobs. Let him also have multiple weapons that he can choose from. Also make him look like he’s wearing Technoblade’s robe.
I love this, so underrated. Then minecraft would have 3 bosses

Now, you would need to change it to be 25% chance on hard, 50% chance on medium, and 100% chance on easy for this to happen, but I think it would make villager price farms harder on hard difficulty. Or maybe just make all of them 100%.

I LOVE IT JUST TAKE OUT THIS PART PLS 

*As long as the chunk containing the Wandering Villager Band's meeting point remains loaded, the Band and its structures will not disappear. But if the chunk becomes unloaded for a long enough period of time, the Band of Wandering Villagers, their Golems (unless Nametagged), and whatever is left of their Tent structures will despawn. Blocks placed by a player will remain, however.*

PLEASE TAKE THIS OUT PRETY PLEASE!!!

There are several points of balance that this idea would add to the game. By preventing players from bringing Netherite into the Deep Dark*, the intensity of a Warden encounter becomes further heightened. If it weren't already apparent that contacting a Warden was a VeryBadIdea, having your Netherite armor taken from you to face the Warden defenseless will.

Adding thieving Goblins into the mix that dart after you to pickpocket Netherite in the darkness strengthens the importance of stealthily exploring near skulk shriekers. If the Darkness effect is triggered, Goblins are in their element.

*Addending sub-Idea: Perhaps if you put Curse of Binding and Curse of Vanishing on your Netherite, the Goblins cannot remove it from you. But when you take it with you, you're playing for Keeps!

Thanks for the reply. I have several gameplay ideas that would build from the addition of Goblins. But I thought it was best to start with trying to build a bit of interest in adding a new race to the game.

In regards to goblins potentially spawning in the Deep Dark, I never took away any impression that the Deep Dark would never get anything other than the Warden; just that the Warden dominates the Deep Dark. I'm looking forward past the introduction of the Deep Dark to suggest some things to enrich the space.

I posted a comment explaining how I would expect Goblins to be implemented, but that comment was rejected without explanation. Maybe I provided too much specific info that time.

The core idea of the race is that there would be two separate classes: Common Goblins and Rogue Goblins. The common goblins would always stay in the Dark. You would never see them or they would be very difficult to see. They don't attack the player. They rob the player and make it harder to explore Ancient Cities with impunity.

Rogue goblins would be more of an adventurer class. They are well armed, travel in bands (similar to pillagers) they can be found above the Deep Dark in caves and very rarely on the surface of the Overworld.

If these were added, there are many additional things that could be done with them.

But the Caves don't have any curated hostiles; they're just the same hostiles as everywhere else. Making goblins roam the caves and the Deep would enliven the space.

I hadn't considered any bartering dynamic. It would fit within this structure to have the Rogue Goblins barter for Netherite ingots, but it wouldn't make a whole lot of sense to trade away Netherite ingots. I can't think of anything that exists within the game already that would be worth giving up Netherite in order to get.

To be honest, I wasn't considering them as a bartering race. Can you think of anything?

Since axolotls spawn in specific underground biomes, I see no reason why we can't have new biome specific creatures like goblins living in the deep.  Goblins are very well known mythological creatures.  We haven't had any new hostile mobs in some time.
I think only in deserts, but this is a good idea
I like this post, but maybe in order for them to become husks, zombies must not have any armor or tools equiped?
sand deaths only
Only ones in a desert would work. Otherwise it would just make zombies too OP

I'd love for more golems, and given the magical theme, I think new golems should be for automating farms, fishing, and lumber work as Quality of Life builds. This would make it so each golem was unique than just "another battle ally" and get rid of the serf vibe using villagers for farming (or expanding to fishermen based on some posts).

I love that the copper golem essentially had an upkeep mechanic so players would have to re-engage with it after a certain amount of time, something that could go forward with other golems as well. As an upkeep requirement in automation of systems, plus could give some very interesting statues. Also adding a mechanic that golems break down over time after being refreshed by an axe, would add more consumption of materials. 

The Copper Golem's mechanic was a bit weak, players have randomized redstone signals with pressure plates and mobs before, and it's not a feature all players use with their play style. Everyone has to gather materials though, spend time planting and harvesting in a very repetitive cycle. Now to balance the may require some unique treasure loot from the deep dark or end, however, worth it in most players mind as a reward.

I think it could also be handy if Wandering Trader Trades were for more than just Emeralds, randomly a trade or two would be an item for emeralds, like 16 lapis for 1 emerald, or 10 phantom flesh for 1 emerald, an enchanted book (say level 1) for 2 Emeralds, items that encourage a "collecting quest" and not otherwise tradable villagers. Another idea would be something like 10 pufferfish for 1 potion of water breathing, or 32 oak saplings for 1 dark oak sapling. Trades like this would feel natural to the idea of a merchant or traveling trader who would also want exotic goods to take back to villages, and gives a player that hasn't found a village or gotten lucky in the mountains a chance to get emeralds or trade for items without needing emeralds.
I had already said this on another comment, but just kill the llamas.

One of my favorite (tombstone/gravestone) inventory-saving ideas was that you're ex-body with all your loot, turns into a zombie that you then have to defeat to reclaim your goods. Which naturally has to be switched off if you have Keep Inventory On, but a fun idea for sure.
I think they should trade emeralds for observers sticky pistons pistons etc.
I really like this idea, but having redstone dust on their clothes might look like blood.
Please note that this kind of small details are the things that make the game beautiful :)
Hola
I want to be the mayor NOW

I like the 2nd idea about villagers changing their trades regularly, maybe I would be wrong but perhaps that would discourage players from trapping villagers in trade halls and instead treat them more humanely and check their trades regularly in hopes that they're selling something good, instead of locking a villager in a good trade and repeatedly zombify+cure them in a cage to get the good trades en masse.

Sometimes I post stuff and don't worry about it not getting a lot of traction, but when it's posts like this one (about remedying certain busted features), I'm disappointed that they seem to go ignored.

Villagers having random trades each day would make players to trap them more, not less. Going round the village and checking what trades each villager has every day would quickly become a chore, so players would trap them in a small area to make it easier. Whereas when a villager keeps the same trade forever, you can let them roam freely in the village and just seek them out when you need them.

This area of the game desperately needs to be addressed. Having to essentially break the game to farm the enchanted books you want from villagers is really frustrating, it really needs to be reworked to feel more rewarding.
The fact that on a server someone always has to be the one that makes a villager trading hall to sell items to everyone else so they don't have to go through the experience themselves says a lot about how fun this part of the game is. When I play on a singleplayer world I dread having to mess with villagers to get the books I want to get a proper "end game" loadout.

There are so many ways for this problem to be fixed. Your idea of villagers changing trades daily seems great. I'm not sure what the broader community would think but basically anything is better than the current state of villager trading and getting the enchantments you want in the game right now.

I could give so many ideas but I don't think I'd even have the room in this comment to list them all. I think the most important thing here is for Mojang to recognize how badly this area of the game needs to be fixed and get the community's ideas through something similar to the combat snapshots.

I'm relatively new to minecraft but to have the option of villager exploit as a feature is definitely very alluring I hope they don't take it out anytime soon it's not like you have to kill the poor villagers or anything you could just give them a Lil room or something idk..
Yeah, nice idea
